question_text: Which of the following accurately describe limitations of parity memory? (Select all that apply)
answer_options: It cannot correct errors—it only detects them
It requires system reboot upon error detection
It stores two parity bits for 16-bit words
It may fail to detect multiple-bit errors
It can be used with ECC-only motherboards
correct_answer: It cannot correct errors—it only detects them
It requires system reboot upon error detection
It may fail to detect multiple-bit errors
explanation: Parity memory detects but does not correct errors. Multiple-bit errors can evade detection, and systems often halt when errors occur.
